awd_titl_txt: Highly Convergent and Stereoselective Synthesis of Heterodimeric Polycyclic Alkaloids
awd_abstract_narration:
With this award, the Chemical Synthesis Program of the Chemistry Division is funding Professor Mohammad Movassaghi of the Department of Chemistry at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology to explore and develop new general methodology for the formation of challenging C-C bonds by directed radical combination reactions.  This project focuses on the development of mild conditions for synthesis of diazenes as intermediates in guided advanced fragment assembly.  An integral part of the study will focus on evaluating and broadening the chemistry of these intermediates in chemical synthesis.  The proposed study includes a thorough development of our preliminary results supported by additional mechanistic probes and studies that will provide important insight into the stereochemical course of these diazene-based assemblies for preparation of complex heterodimeric polycyclic alkaloids.

Such chemistry will provide precedence of a general strategy in controlled complex chemical synthesis that will have broad impact in pharmaceutical, agricultural, and fine-chemical industries where designed complex molecules are used in biological and chemical research endeavors.  The broader impacts involve training graduate students and postdoctoral researchers, broadening participation through the inclusion of undergraduate and visiting student researchers on the project, and continued contribution by the research group to MIT's Chemistry Outreach Program at local high schools.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
The field of synthetic organic chemistry provides access to precious molecules, including natural products, in a versatile manner. The precise assembly and refinement of complex molecules in synthetic organic chemistry, many with important biological or physical properties, provides access to these molecules in addition to designed derivatives with enhanced properties. Efficient synthesis of rare natural products provides samples necessary for detailed examination, leading to understanding of their mode of action and mechanistic basis for their function. The development and application of new methodology in complex settings serves as a precedent for broader utility in the synthesis of other molecules of interest in pharmaceutical, agricultural, and fine-chemical industries where designed complex molecules are used in biological and chemical research endeavors. In this research program, we developed new chemical synthesis strategies and methodologies to overcome major challenges in complex molecule synthesis. Specifically, we developed and advanced a key strategy for union of two complex molecules that allows for a convergent and efficient assembly of more complex alkaloid molecules. We applied our diazene-mediated fragment-assembly, a process that allows guided union of two different and complex fragments, thus allowing us to prepare a previously inaccessible heterodimeric intermediate. The application of this synthetic strategy ultimately led to the completion of the first biomimetic total synthesis of communesin F via a highly efficient and convergent approach. We successfully prepared both fragments using latest advances in asymmetric synthetsis, and developed new and mild reaction conditions for synthesis of a key diazene intermediate necessary for formation of the key carbon-carbon bond bringing two halves of the molecule together. This project provided an excellent arena for research coworkers to develop their organic synthetic chemistry skills in the context of designing, developing, executing, and analyzing complex chemical transformation. Additionally, each year my coworkers and I volunteered at the Cambridge Science Festival with the aim of introducing the general public to the impact of the science of synthetic organic chemistry and the total chemical synthesis of complex molecules.


Last Modified: 11/24/2016
Modified by: Mohammad Movassaghi
